facts.text: Civil Appeal No.18 of 1961 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL, APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.18 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 23,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 23, 1960 of Madhya Pradesh High Court at Indore in Second Appeal No. 473 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 23, 1960, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Indore in Second Appeal No. 473 of 1959. F. Bootwala, E. Udayarathanam and S.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 5, 1961 by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-This appeal raises the question whether the suit filed by the appellants was

facts.text: Appellants filed suit for declaration that they were citizens of India and injunction restraining defendants from removing them from India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had filed the suit for a declaration that they were citizens of India and for an injunction restraining the defendants from removing them from India. The defendants were the Union of India, the State of Madhya Pradesh and the District Magistrate, Jhabua, in Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Defendants were Union of India, State of Madhya Pradesh and District Magistrate, Jhabua, Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants were the Union of India, the State of Madhya Pradesh and the District Magistrate, Jhabua, in Madhya Pradesh. The appellants stated in the plaint that they were citizens of India and had number ceased to be such citizens.

facts.text: Appellants stated they were citizens of India and had not ceased to be such citizens.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants stated in the plaint that they were citizens of India and had number ceased to be such citizens. They said that in the beginning of 1953 they went to Pakistan for a temporary visit without a passport but when they wanted to return they were companypelled to obtain Pakistani passports.

facts.text: Appellants went to Pakistan for temporary visit without passport in beginning of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: They said that in the beginning of 1953 they went to Pakistan for a temporary visit without a passport but when they wanted to return they were companypelled to obtain Pakistani passports. They stated that they obtained these passports only as a device for securing their return to India and had really been companypelled to obtain the passports against their will.

facts.text: Appellants obtained Pakistani passports as device to return to India, compelled against their will.

anchor.surface_text: They stated that they obtained these passports only as a device for securing their return to India and had really been companypelled to obtain the passports against their will. They further stated that, therefore, they companyld number be said to have acquired citizenship of Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellants had not acquired citizenship of Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: They further stated that, therefore, they companyld number be said to have acquired citizenship of Pakistan. They also stated that they had made all efforts for the cancellation of the passports and to obtain permission to stay in India permanently but were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appellants made efforts for cancellation of passports and permission to stay in India permanently but unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: They also stated that they had made all efforts for the cancellation of the passports and to obtain permission to stay in India permanently but were unsuccessful. They said that the State of Madhya Pradesh served on them an order dated November 11, 1955, under s. 3 2  of the Foreigners Act, 1946, asking them to leave the companyntry.

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh served order dated November 11, 1955 under s. 3(2) of Foreigners Act 1946 asking appellants to leave the country.

anchor.surface_text: They said that the State of Madhya Pradesh served on them an order dated November 11, 1955, under s. 3 2  of the Foreigners Act, 1946, asking them to leave the companyntry. They companytend that this order was illegal and without justification as they were number foreigners.

facts.text: Appellants left India between March and May 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In the written statement filed by the defendants it was stated that the appellants had left India between March and May, 1948, and they returned for the first time on a temporary Pakistani passport sometime in the early part of 1955.

facts.text: Appellants returned to India first time on temporary Pakistani passport in early part of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and they returned for the first time on a temporary Pakistani passport sometime in the early part of 1955. It was also stated that the permits granted to them to remain in India were extended from time to time and ultimately up to about October, 1955, and thereafter they were served with orders to quit India.

facts.text: Permits to remain in India extended up to about October 1955, then served orders to quit India.

anchor.surface_text: It was also stated that the permits granted to them to remain in India were extended from time to time and ultimately up to about October, 1955, and thereafter they were served with orders to quit India. The defendants further stated that the appellants were number citizens of India as they had voluntarily acquired Pakistani citizenship by obtaining passports from that companyntry .

facts.text: Appellants voluntarily acquired Pakistani citizenship by obtaining passports.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants further stated that the appellants were number citizens of India as they had voluntarily acquired Pakistani citizenship by obtaining passports from that companyntry . The suit was dismissed as it was held number to be maintainable in view of the provisions of sub-see.  2  of a. 9 of the Citizenship Act.

facts.text: Courts below dismissed suit holding no jurisdiction due to s.9(2) Citizenship Act 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed as it was held number to be maintainable in view of the provisions of sub-see.  2  of a. 9 of the Citizenship Act. That sub-section is in these terms Section 9  2 . If any question arises as to whether, when or how any person has acquired the citizenship of another companyntry, it shall be determined by such authority, in such manner, and having regard to such rule- of evidence, as may be prescribed in this behalf.

facts.text: Suit raised question whether appellants lost Indian citizenship by acquiring Pakistani citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the suit by the appellants raised the question whether they had lost their Indian citizenship by acquiring the citizenship of Pakistan. The appellants themselves had raised that question by pleading in their -plaint that they had number voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellants' claim resisted on ground of migration to Pakistan in 1948, never acquired Indian citizenship under Art.7 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim to the citizenship of India was resisted on the ground that having migrated to Pakistan in 1948, they had never acquired Indian citizenship. That might follow from Art. 7 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside orders and judgments of courts below.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons earlier stated, we set aside the orders and the judgments of the Courts below and direct that the suit be heard and decided on all questions raised in it excepting the question whether the appellants having been Indian citizens for sometime have renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship.

facts.text: Attorney-General conceded position that civil court jurisdiction not entirely barred except by s.9 Citizenship Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General appearing for the respondents, the defendants in the suit, companyceded this position. He did number companytend that there was any other bar to the suit excepting that created by s. 9 of the Citizenship Act.

facts.text: Rule 30 of Rules under Citizenship Act: question determined by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 30 of the Rules framed under this Act provides that such a question shall be determined by the Central Government, who for that purpose shall have regard to the rules of evidence specified in Schedule III to the Rules.

facts.text: Appellants contend order under Foreigners Act illegal as they are not foreigners.

anchor.surface_text: They companytend that this order was illegal and without justification as they were number foreigners. In the written statement filed by the defendants it was stated that the appellants had left India between March and May, 1948,

facts.text: Supreme Court directs suit to be heard on all questions except whether appellants renounced Indian citizenship and acquired foreign citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: and direct that the suit be heard and decided on all questions raised in it excepting the question whether the appellants having been Indian citizens for sometime have renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship. If the Court finds that the appellants had never been Indian citizens, then the suit, would be dismissed by it.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed as it was held number to be maintainable in view of the provisions of sub-see.  2  of a. 9 of the Citizenship Act. That sub-section is in these terms Section 9  2 . If any question arises as to whether, when or how any person has acquired the citizenship of another companyntry, it shall be determined by such authority, in such manner, and having regard to such rule- of evidence, as may be prescribed in this behalf.

concepts.interpretation: Bars civil court jurisdiction only to determine whether, when or how an Indian citizen has acquired citizenship of another country; does not bar determination of other nationality questions, such as whether a person ever became an Indian citizen.

concepts.interpretation: Central Government determines questions under Section 9(2) having regard to rules of evidence in Schedule III.

arguments.claim: s.9(2) Citizenship Act bars civil court jurisdiction on question whether, when or how any person has acquired citizenship of another country

anchor.surface_text: That sub-section is in these terms Section 9 (2) . If any question arises as to whether, when or how any person has acquired the citizenship of another country, it shall be determined by such authority, in such manner, and having regard to such rule- of evidence, as may be prescribed in this behalf. Rule 30 of the Rules

arguments.claim: civil courts prevented only from determining whether Indian citizen acquired foreign citizenship or when/how; other nationality questions not barred

anchor.surface_text: The only question, however, which a civil court is prevented by s. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act from determining is the question whether a citizen of India has acquired citizenship of another country or when or how he acquired it. The civil courts are not prevented by this provision from determining other questions concerning nationality of a person.

holdings.text: Sub-section (2) of section 9 of the Citizenship Act bars the jurisdiction of the civil court to try the question whether, when or how any person has acquired the citizenship of another country.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that sub-see.  2  of B. 9 of the Citizenship Act bars the jurisdiction of the civil companyrt to try the question there mentioned because it says that those questions shall be determined by the prescribed authority which necessarily implies that it cannot be decided by anyone else.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language mandates determination by prescribed authority (Central Government per Rule 30), implying exclusive jurisdiction.

holdings.text: A civil court is prevented by section 9(2) from determining only whether a citizen of India has acquired citizenship of another country or when or how.

anchor.surface_text: The only question, however, which a civil companyrt is prevented by s. 9 2  of the Citizenship Act from determining is the question whether a citizen of India has acquired citizenship of another companyntry or when or how he acquired it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow textual reading limits bar to specific questions phrased in the section.

holdings.text: Civil courts are not prevented by section 9(2) from determining other questions concerning nationality of a person.

anchor.surface_text: The civil companyrts are number prevented by this provision from determining other questions companycerning nationality of a person. There is numberdoubt that the suit by the appellants raised the question whether they had lost their Indian citizenship by acquiring the citizenship of Pakistan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section does not mention other nationality issues like initial acquisition of Indian citizenship.

holdings.text: The suit raised the question whether the appellants had lost Indian citizenship by acquiring Pakistani citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the suit by the appellants raised the question whether they had lost their Indian citizenship by acquiring the citizenship of Pakistan. The appellants themselves had raised that question by pleading in their -plaint

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants' plaint explicitly pleaded no voluntary acquisition of Pakistani citizenship.

holdings.text: To that extent, the appellants' suit was barred by section 9(2).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants themselves had raised that question by pleading in their -plaint that they had number voluntarily acquired the citizenship of Pakistan. To that extent, it has to be held that the appellants suit was barred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit directly invokes the barred question.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction of civil court to decide whether appellants had never been Indian citizens is not affected by section 9(2).

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction of a civil companyrt to decide that question is number in any way affected by s. 9 2  of the Citizenship Act. Therefore it seems to us that the entire suit should number have been dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Barred question presupposes existing Indian citizenship; prior status falls outside scope.

holdings.text: The entire suit should not have been dismissed; courts below should have decided whether appellants had never been Indian citizens.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore it seems to us that the entire suit should number have been dismissed. The Courts below should have decided the question whether the appellants had never been Indian citizens. If that question was answered in the affirmative, then numberfurther question would arise and the suit would have to be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial bar does not justify dismissing entire suit; separable issues.

holdings.text: If appellants found to have been Indian citizens on January 26, 1950, court should stay suit pending Central Government's decision on whether they subsequently acquired foreign citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: If it was found that the appellants had been on January 26, 1950, Indian citizens, then only the question whether they had renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship would arise. That question the Courts cannot decide. The proper thing for the companyrt would then have been to stay the suit till the Central Government decided the question whether the appellants had renounced their Indian citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship and then dispose of the rest of the suit in such manner as the decision of the Central

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical sequencing: resolve initial citizenship first, then defer barred question to prescribed authority.

holdings.text: A competent legislature may take away civil court's jurisdiction to try other questions also, not limited to rights created by the statute with exclusive tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this companytention. A companypetent legislature may take away a civil companyrts jurisdiction to try other questions also. No authority has been shown that this cannot be done. Another argument advanced by him was that the appellants had numberright to approach the Central Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow view of ouster clauses; no authority limits legislative power.

holdings.text: Orders and judgments of courts below set aside; suit to be heard on all questions except whether appellants, having been Indian citizens, renounced and acquired foreign citizenship.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons earlier stated, we set aside the orders and the judgments of the Courts below and direct that the suit be heard and decided on all questions raised in it excepting the question whether the appellants having been Indian citizens for sometime have renounced that citizenship and acquired a foreign citizenship. If the Court finds that the appellants had never been Indian citizens, then the suit, would be dismissed by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above holdings to remand with directions.

holdings.text: View in Sharafat Ali Khan v. State of U.P. that no right to approach Central Government means no ouster of civil court is open to grave doubt.

anchor.surface_text: This question really does number arise because the learned Attorney General appearing for the respondents has companyceded the appellants right to apply to the Central Government for a decision of the question. Even apart from this companycession the view expressed in Sharafat Ali Khan v. State of U. P.  1  would seem to be open to grave doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; does not arise due to concession; expresses doubt on precedent.
